question.title: How do I access an array list inside of a class constructor in java?

node.contents: a constructor is a constructor. i have no idea why did you declare your arraylist inside the constructor

astNode.text: a constructor is a constructor. i have no idea why did you declare your arraylist inside the constructor

node.contents: I constructed a Purse class with the following:

astNode.text: I constructed a Purse class with the following:

elements.contents: public Purse(){ ArrayList<String> coins = new ArrayList(); }

units.rawText: public Purse(){ ArrayList<String> coins = new ArrayList(); }

node.contents: My function to add strings to the object:

astNode.text: My function to add strings to the object:

node.contents: This idea is that each Purse object can hold a list of strings. I cannot, however, access the ArrayList<String> coins with my methods.

astNode.text: This idea is that each Purse object can hold a list of strings. I cannot, however, access the ArrayList<String> coins with my methods.

node.contents: For example, this method I wrote to reverse the order of the strings

astNode.text: For example, this method I wrote to reverse the order of the strings

elements.contents: public void reverse(){ for (int j = coins.size() - 2; j > -1; j--){ coins.add(coins.get(j)); coins.remove(j); }

units.rawText:
public void reverse(){ for (int j = coins.size() - 2; j > -1; j--){ coins.add(coins.get(j)); coins.remove(j); } ...
}

node.contents: calls the error that the symbol coins cannot be found.

astNode.text: calls the error that the symbol coins cannot be found.

node.contents: How do I make it so that my methods can access the array list I made inside of my constructor? Do I need to say something along the lines of this.coins.add(coinName) for the void addCoin method or this.coins.add(this.coins.get(j)) for the reverse method?

astNode.text: How do I make it so that my methods can access the array list I made inside of my constructor? Do I need to say something along the lines of this.coins.add(coinName) for the void addCoin method or this.coins.add(this.coins.get(j)) for the reverse method?

node.contents: Okay, that worked. Also, I didn't realize that I need to use `this.coins.get()` (or something along those lines). I forgot that I need to clarify which `ArrayList` I'm calling.

astNode.text: Okay, that worked. Also, I didn't realize that I need to use `this.coins.get()` (or something along those lines). I forgot that I need to clarify which `ArrayList` I'm calling.

node.contents: You need to move the declaration of coins outside the constructor:

astNode.text: You need to move the declaration of coins outside the constructor:

elements.contents: private List<String> coins; public Purse(){ coins = new ArrayList<String>(); }

units.rawText: private List<String> coins; public Purse(){ coins = new ArrayList<String>(); }

node.contents: This would make coins a private field of your class, making it accessible from all non-static methods of the Purse. Currently, you are creating a local variable coins which becomes inaccessible when constructor exits.

astNode.text: This would make coins a private field of your class, making it accessible from all non-static methods of the Purse. Currently, you are creating a local variable coins which becomes inaccessible when constructor exits.

elements.contents: // e.g. define it here. private ArrayList<String> coins; public Purse() { // construct it here. coins = new ArrayList(); }

comments.text: // construct it here. coins = new ArrayList(); }

node.contents: +1 for using the `List` interface as the reference type.

astNode.text: +1 for using the `List` interface as the reference type.

node.contents: Declare the ArrayList as a field outside of the constructor. Also use the List interface instead of ArrayList.

astNode.text: Declare the ArrayList as a field outside of the constructor. Also use the List interface instead of ArrayList.

elements.contents: public class Purse{ private List<String> coins= new ArrayList<String>(); public Purse(){ } }

units.rawText: public class Purse{ private List<String> coins= new ArrayList<String>(); public Purse(){ } }

node.contents: When declared inside the constructor the scope of the list is limited to the constructor method. Declared as a field in the class, the List will be accessible by all methods inside the class.

astNode.text: When declared inside the constructor the scope of the list is limited to the constructor method. Declared as a field in the class, the List will be accessible by all methods inside the class.

node.contents: By declaring the coins variable inside of the constructor, you are making the variable local to the constructor block. Once you are outside of the block then the coins variable is no longer accessible.

astNode.text: By declaring the coins variable inside of the constructor, you are making the variable local to the constructor block. Once you are outside of the block then the coins variable is no longer accessible.

node.contents: As a result, declare the coins as an instance variable of your Purse class.

astNode.text: As a result, declare the coins as an instance variable of your Purse class.

elements.contents: public class Purse { private List<String> coins; public Purse() { coins = new ArrayList<String>(); } }

units.rawText: public class Purse { private List<String> coins; public Purse() { coins = new ArrayList<String>(); } }
